episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike look at working with directory services. They explain what a directory service is and the benefits of using a directory service. They demonstrate joining a MacBook to an Active Directory domain as well as an Apple OpenDirectory.
episodes.title: Directory Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.755
Welcome to ITProTV, I am your host
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.755 --> 00:00:08.380
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.380 --> 00:00:11.918
>> Your watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.918 --> 00:00:15.827
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.827 --> 00:00:19.863
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our Mac Integration Basics.

6
00:00:19.863 --> 00:00:21.531
And specifically in this episode,

7
00:00:21.531 --> 00:00:24.510
we're gonna be taking a look
at directory services.

8
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:26.570
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.570 --> 00:00:27.540
Welcome Don.

10
00:00:27.540 --> 00:00:29.390
>> Thanks for having me, Mike,
we're ready to dive right in and

11
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:31.470
tackle some directory services.

12
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:34.860
Now, we probably need to kick things off
with, what do you think, some basics?

13
00:00:34.860 --> 00:00:37.470
>> Yeah,
I'm thinking what is a directory service?

14
00:00:37.470 --> 00:00:38.482
What do we mean by that?

15
00:00:38.482 --> 00:00:40.253
It'd be a good place to start, right?

16
00:00:40.253 --> 00:00:43.506
>> All right, well for a lot of us, when
you buy a new Mac, you power it on, and

17
00:00:43.506 --> 00:00:46.326
it asks you what your name is,
and you punch it in there, right?

18
00:00:46.326 --> 00:00:48.480
And maybe you choose to set a password,
maybe you don't.

19
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:50.710
And when you're done,
now you've got your Mac.

20
00:00:50.710 --> 00:00:53.210
A lot of people set their Macs up
to do automatic logins, right?

21
00:00:53.210 --> 00:00:56.600
So you just turn on your laptop or
your desktop, and

22
00:00:56.600 --> 00:01:00.060
it powers on, goes right into
the operating system, and off you go.

23
00:01:00.060 --> 00:01:04.210
And for a home user, that's fine,
that works out great, right?

24
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:05.830
But even for

25
00:01:05.830 --> 00:01:08.580
a home user there are scenarios where
that can start to become problematic.

26
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:11.320
What if I have two or three Macs?

27
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:13.812
Okay, well I can set them up
to automatically log on too.

28
00:01:13.812 --> 00:01:16.196
And then we'll just go or
I set them up with the same password.

29
00:01:16.196 --> 00:01:17.509
I'll put the same password on all three,
great.

30
00:01:17.509 --> 00:01:19.695
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, but

31
00:01:19.695 --> 00:01:23.730
what if I have Macs that I want to share,
right?

32
00:01:23.730 --> 00:01:25.250
For a home, this might be your family.

33
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:29.180
You might have a husband, wife, kids,
whatever, that all wanna share a Mac.

34
00:01:29.180 --> 00:01:31.970
But they want separate profiles, right?

35
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:34.360
Separate wallpapers, separate documents,

36
00:01:34.360 --> 00:01:36.510
they want to kind of keep
their stuff separate.

37
00:01:36.510 --> 00:01:41.070
Or maybe it's a workplace, where maybe
you're a real estate organization, and

38
00:01:41.070 --> 00:01:44.010
you've got a hundred realtors.

39
00:01:44.010 --> 00:01:47.260
Meanwhile, you just have
ten computers set up.

40
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:48.430
I don't need 100 computers,

41
00:01:48.430 --> 00:01:51.280
cuz the realtors should be out there
in the field showing houses, right?

42
00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:53.000
But when they come back,
they use shared computers but

43
00:01:53.000 --> 00:01:56.290
I want them to have separate
identities on these computers.

44
00:01:56.290 --> 00:01:58.760
Well that means we're gonna have
to set up separate user accounts.

45
00:01:58.760 --> 00:02:01.870
And that's easy on one computer.

46
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:03.280
But what if I have five computers?

47
00:02:03.280 --> 00:02:03.807
What if I have ten?

48
00:02:03.807 --> 00:02:05.800
What if I have 1,000 computers?

49
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:10.290
Think about a school, a university,
you might have thousands of computers.

50
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:14.540
And every time a new student enrolls,
I don't wanna have to go and

51
00:02:14.540 --> 00:02:17.900
create an account for them,
on all of the computers.

52
00:02:17.900 --> 00:02:20.460
If I have 3,000 computers, I don't
wanna have to go to 3,000 computers and

53
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:21.780
create that account.

54
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:23.840
And god forbid if somebody
wants to change their password.

55
00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:25.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't want them have

56
00:02:25.430 --> 00:02:27.770
to go to 3,000 computers to
change their password, right?

57
00:02:27.770 --> 00:02:29.650
It's just not possible.

58
00:02:29.650 --> 00:02:32.250
When you start getting into environments
like that, things become too complex.

59
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:35.340
>> So there's gotta be some way then
that we can kind of centralize this.

60
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:37.780
A place where I don't have to have
a separate account for each and

61
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:38.620
every machine.

62
00:02:38.620 --> 00:02:40.779
>> And that's exactly what
a directory service does, right?

63
00:02:40.779 --> 00:02:43.607
It says, hey,
instead of storing the user accounts and

64
00:02:43.607 --> 00:02:47.414
passwords right there in each individual
machine, which is the default.

65
00:02:47.414 --> 00:02:49.454
We'll store the user accounts and

66
00:02:49.454 --> 00:02:53.334
passwords in a centralized
database stored somewhere, right?

67
00:02:53.334 --> 00:02:54.089
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

68
00:02:54.089 --> 00:02:55.313
>> That somewhere is hopefully

69
00:02:55.313 --> 00:02:58.000
managed by your IT department and
in their server room.

70
00:02:58.000 --> 00:03:01.742
But it could be even further remote,
something like an Apple ID, right?

71
00:03:01.742 --> 00:03:04.850
A lot of us use Apple IDs
to log in to Macs now.

72
00:03:04.850 --> 00:03:09.840
And those are stored in a directory server
that's located in Apple's data centers,

73
00:03:09.840 --> 00:03:10.890
right, so that's one option.

74
00:03:10.890 --> 00:03:13.010
Now we don't control that option.

75
00:03:13.010 --> 00:03:18.120
If we wanna control it ourselves, any IT
department can set up a directory server.

76
00:03:18.120 --> 00:03:21.690
And a directory server is a server
that runs a directory service.

77
00:03:21.690 --> 00:03:26.279
And a directory service is merely
a database of user accounts and passwords,

78
00:03:26.279 --> 00:03:26.780
right?

79
00:03:26.780 --> 00:03:30.680
And they can do a lot more, there's a ton
of bells and whistles that they can have.

80
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:36.990
But at the deep down brass tacks of it,
it's just a database of user accounts.

81
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:40.267
And when you go to log in to a computer,
you sit down, and you go to punching your

82
00:03:40.267 --> 00:03:43.900
username and your password, your computer
is not looking at its own users.

83
00:03:43.900 --> 00:03:45.878
Now it's reaching out over the network.

84
00:03:45.878 --> 00:03:47.550
And it's asking a directory
service saying,

85
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:50.490
hey, somebody just gave me
this username and password.

86
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:51.407
Is it any good?

87
00:03:51.407 --> 00:03:53.460
And it shares it with that server.

88
00:03:53.460 --> 00:03:55.450
And the directory server will look at it.

89
00:03:55.450 --> 00:03:59.120
And it will say, yeah, that's good,
or, no, that's not good.

90
00:03:59.120 --> 00:04:00.750
And then your laptop, your desktop,

91
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:03.860
whatever it is that you're logging into,
will make a decision based on that.

92
00:04:03.860 --> 00:04:07.500
So directory service is really
important in the enterprise space,

93
00:04:07.500 --> 00:04:08.590
in the business world.

94
00:04:08.590 --> 00:04:10.415
>> Does that help us with
the whole password thing?

95
00:04:10.415 --> 00:04:12.888
Do still have to change my password
in all these different places?

96
00:04:12.888 --> 00:04:14.870
>> Well, since it's all stored centrally,

97
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:18.825
if I change my password on one computer,
it's effectively changed everywhere.

98
00:04:18.825 --> 00:04:20.350
It's not truly changed everywhere,

99
00:04:20.350 --> 00:04:22.590
its just changed at one place,
in the directory.

100
00:04:22.590 --> 00:04:24.210
Cuz that's where everybody looks, right?

101
00:04:24.210 --> 00:04:28.040
So Mike if your laptop was joined to
a directory and my laptop was joined to

102
00:04:28.040 --> 00:04:31.900
a directory, I can log in on my
computer and change my password.

103
00:04:31.900 --> 00:04:34.250
I can immediately walk over to yours and

104
00:04:34.250 --> 00:04:37.540
log in with my new password and
it'll work.

105
00:04:37.540 --> 00:04:41.060
Because Mike's laptop would also be
looking to the directory server and

106
00:04:41.060 --> 00:04:41.770
not looking locally.

107
00:04:41.770 --> 00:04:44.560
If it was looking locally, I'd have
to go and change it on every machine.

108
00:04:44.560 --> 00:04:45.699
It's a nightmare, it's just not possible.

109
00:04:46.780 --> 00:04:50.250
>> All right, Don, so now we've got
an idea of what a directory service is,

110
00:04:50.250 --> 00:04:52.730
are there different ones available?

111
00:04:52.730 --> 00:04:53.812
How do we know which one to use?

112
00:04:53.812 --> 00:04:56.000
>> So there's a ton available.

113
00:04:56.000 --> 00:04:57.810
And as far as which one we use,

114
00:04:57.810 --> 00:04:59.820
it's usually not even a decision
we get to make, right?

115
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:03.445
So if you work in an enterprise
environment, your business,

116
00:05:03.445 --> 00:05:05.660
we'll already have a directory.

117
00:05:05.660 --> 00:05:06.570
Even small and

118
00:05:06.570 --> 00:05:10.650
medium sized businesses will typically
already have a directory of some sort.

119
00:05:10.650 --> 00:05:12.940
So the decision is likely
already been made.

120
00:05:12.940 --> 00:05:16.589
And well, the name of the show is Mac
Integration Basics which we're trying to

121
00:05:16.589 --> 00:05:19.700
integrate our Mac into whatever
environment we've already got.

122
00:05:19.700 --> 00:05:24.140
Well fortunately, most directory
servers conform to a certain standard.

123
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:26.270
And that means it's pretty
easy to get connected.

124
00:05:26.270 --> 00:05:30.386
So there's a standard out
there that's called LDAP.

125
00:05:30.386 --> 00:05:32.870
And well LDAP is actually
the protocol we use to talk, so

126
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:36.290
the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.

127
00:05:36.290 --> 00:05:40.390
And LDAP let's us talk to a directory
of user accounts and say, hey,

128
00:05:40.390 --> 00:05:41.910
I just got this username and password.

129
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:43.120
Is everything good?

130
00:05:43.120 --> 00:05:45.400
And get an answer back,
right, that's what LDAP does.

131
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:47.650
Well, there's a number of vendors
out there that have created

132
00:05:47.650 --> 00:05:49.270
directory services.

133
00:05:49.270 --> 00:05:53.100
And most of them have taken the time
to make those directory services

134
00:05:53.100 --> 00:05:54.820
compatible with LDAP.

135
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:57.810
And so we have this thing called OpenLDAP,

136
00:05:57.810 --> 00:06:00.290
which is an open-source
implementation of LDAP.

137
00:06:00.290 --> 00:06:03.240
And as long as the systems are conforming
with that, we can connect and

138
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:04.740
we can join up, right?

139
00:06:04.740 --> 00:06:07.375
So the two directories that we need
to know for the exam are probably

140
00:06:07.375 --> 00:06:10.310
the two more common ones that
you'll see out there in the field.

141
00:06:10.310 --> 00:06:15.610
And that is Apple's Open Directory and
Microsoft's Active Directory.

142
00:06:15.610 --> 00:06:17.860
Both of which use LDAP.

143
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:19.330
They both use LDAP to communicate.

144
00:06:19.330 --> 00:06:20.610
And so that means it's very easy for

145
00:06:20.610 --> 00:06:22.452
us to integrate our Macs
to be able to support them.

146
00:06:22.452 --> 00:06:23.628
>> Nice.

147
00:06:23.628 --> 00:06:26.870
>> Now it does depend on
which one your business runs.

148
00:06:26.870 --> 00:06:30.350
And I'll be honest with you,
it doesn't matter if you love Microsoft or

149
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:31.480
hate Microsoft, but

150
00:06:31.480 --> 00:06:34.790
Microsoft's Active Directory is actually
one of the best directory servers.

151
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:37.070
And as a result it is the most common one.

152
00:06:37.070 --> 00:06:39.510
When you're out there for
small business, medium business,

153
00:06:39.510 --> 00:06:43.620
enterprise, government, Microsoft's
Active Directory is one of the biggest.

154
00:06:43.620 --> 00:06:45.780
You'll find it most everywhere.

155
00:06:45.780 --> 00:06:47.100
There are other ones.

156
00:06:47.100 --> 00:06:51.140
Apple's own Open Directory is part of
the server app that you can install.

157
00:06:51.140 --> 00:06:53.949
So if you've got the server app installed,
you can bring up Mac's or

158
00:06:53.949 --> 00:06:55.460
Apple's Open Directory.

159
00:06:55.460 --> 00:06:59.330
It works well but it's a very,
very limited feature set.

160
00:06:59.330 --> 00:07:04.150
It really focuses just on authenticating
users, that's its primary goal.

161
00:07:04.150 --> 00:07:07.690
So Apple's Open Directory is a good
product, it's very easy to deploy, right?

162
00:07:07.690 --> 00:07:10.400
That's the point of most Apple products,
right, it just works.

163
00:07:11.470 --> 00:07:13.650
But as a trade off,
we lose a lot of functionality,

164
00:07:13.650 --> 00:07:17.710
a lot of powerful features that a lot
of businesses have come to count on.

165
00:07:17.710 --> 00:07:19.740
With Microsoft's Active Directory, boy,

166
00:07:19.740 --> 00:07:21.970
you've got a ton of features
jammed into that thing.

167
00:07:21.970 --> 00:07:23.730
It's very, very powerful.

168
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:26.600
It's also very complex,
very hard to set up.

169
00:07:26.600 --> 00:07:28.810
It's not a click a button and
it's up running,

170
00:07:28.810 --> 00:07:30.910
there's a lot of planning
that has to go into it.

171
00:07:30.910 --> 00:07:32.330
But there is a lot of power there.

172
00:07:32.330 --> 00:07:35.400
And so you'll see it used
in a lot of organizations.

173
00:07:35.400 --> 00:07:36.600
There's other ones, too.

174
00:07:36.600 --> 00:07:38.840
Novell eDirectory comes to mind.

175
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:42.969
Some people still use domains,
which are from the Unix world.

176
00:07:42.969 --> 00:07:45.780
Kerberos Realms which
are also from the Unix world.

177
00:07:45.780 --> 00:07:47.670
There's a few other technologies
that are out there.

178
00:07:47.670 --> 00:07:51.570
And because Mac OS is running
on top of a BSD kernel,

179
00:07:51.570 --> 00:07:55.949
it actually supports a lot of that,
you can tie to those.

180
00:07:55.949 --> 00:07:59.762
But for the exam, and in the graphical
user interface on our system,

181
00:07:59.762 --> 00:08:02.722
what you're really going to
see is a tendency towards

182
00:08:02.722 --> 00:08:06.243
Microsoft's Active Directory and
the Apple Open Directory.

183
00:08:06.243 --> 00:08:07.990
Those are the two that we're gonna see.

184
00:08:07.990 --> 00:08:08.760
>> Fantastic Don.

185
00:08:08.760 --> 00:08:13.120
So now you're saying Microsoft
Active Directory, I'm running a Mac.

186
00:08:14.300 --> 00:08:17.430
Can I still bring this to work,
and am I able to join that domain?

187
00:08:17.430 --> 00:08:18.120
>> Absolutely.

188
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:19.720
Yeah, the support is baked right in.

189
00:08:19.720 --> 00:08:22.002
We just need to get it configured and
get it up and running.

190
00:08:22.002 --> 00:08:25.620
So the configuration side of this
is really gonna be two pieces.

191
00:08:25.620 --> 00:08:28.376
There's the server side piece
configuring the directory and

192
00:08:28.376 --> 00:08:31.609
then there's the work station side
piece which is what we need to know for

193
00:08:31.609 --> 00:08:34.420
the exam,
how to get our Mac join to that directory.

194
00:08:34.420 --> 00:08:36.170
You'll find the server side piece.

195
00:08:36.170 --> 00:08:39.590
It's actually pretty similar across
the different products that are out there.

196
00:08:39.590 --> 00:08:42.300
And I know this is a Mac show, but
let me show you what it looks like.

197
00:08:42.300 --> 00:08:46.240
I'm gonna jump over to a Windows
server here, I've got one here.

198
00:08:46.240 --> 00:08:50.720
So this is a Windows server that is up and
acting as an Active Directory.

199
00:08:50.720 --> 00:08:55.395
And if I go into its Active Directory
users and computers.

200
00:08:55.395 --> 00:08:59.545
I'm just gonna drill into this real quick,
and

201
00:08:59.545 --> 00:09:04.947
what we're going to see is
basically a list of user accounts.

202
00:09:04.947 --> 00:09:07.243
And i'm gonna see user
accounts as well as groups, so

203
00:09:07.243 --> 00:09:08.885
it's actually kind of mixture here.

204
00:09:08.885 --> 00:09:11.591
Let me just kinda get the users together,
so

205
00:09:11.591 --> 00:09:15.040
actually I got three users
out of this whole giant list.

206
00:09:15.040 --> 00:09:15.596
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

207
00:09:15.596 --> 00:09:20.750
here's these user accounts that are being
stored in a centralized directory.

208
00:09:20.750 --> 00:09:23.470
And if I want somebody like
Mike to be able to login and

209
00:09:23.470 --> 00:09:28.380
authenticate, I would need to come
in here and create that account.

210
00:09:28.380 --> 00:09:31.570
So I can come in here and
I can create a new user.

211
00:09:32.590 --> 00:09:35.410
And when I specify the user,
I just need to provide some information.

212
00:09:35.410 --> 00:09:39.491
So this might be Mike Rodrick,
and I'll give him a log in name,

213
00:09:39.491 --> 00:09:42.200
however it is I want it to be, right?

214
00:09:42.200 --> 00:09:44.310
Now notice the different
log in names that show up.

215
00:09:44.310 --> 00:09:47.810
This is kind of important,
because in the Apple world,

216
00:09:47.810 --> 00:09:49.700
we're used to just seeing one name.

217
00:09:49.700 --> 00:09:53.850
It's usually our full names so
like mine would be Don space Pezet.

218
00:09:53.850 --> 00:09:56.990
But in the background,
you've actually got Unix under the hood.

219
00:09:56.990 --> 00:09:59.490
And you'll have a second
user name that you don't

220
00:09:59.490 --> 00:10:01.590
usually see inside of the Mac world right?

221
00:10:01.590 --> 00:10:02.572
So there's this kind of hidden user name.

222
00:10:02.572 --> 00:10:05.891
Well in Microsoft's Active Directoty
is the same way,

223
00:10:05.891 --> 00:10:08.650
you've got different

00:32:20.850 --> 00:32:23.820
or that open directory if
we've got a Mac solution.

674
00:32:23.820 --> 00:32:25.152
But, we thank you for that and

675
00:32:25.152 --> 00:32:27.562
hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

676
00:32:27.562 --> 00:32:30.870
Signing for ITProTv,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

677
00:32:30.870 --> 00:32:31.450
>> And I'm Don Pozet.

678
00:32:31.450 --> 00:32:33.241
>> And we'll see you next time

679
00:32:33.241 --> 00:32:39.210
[MUSIC]

680
00:32:39.210 --> 00:32:42.537
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss connecting to a network file server using various protocols. They demonstrate how to connect by browsing the network, as well as manually entering the information. They also demonstrate how to enable file sharing and share a folder using macOS.
episodes.title: File Sharing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.357
Welcome to ITProTV,
I am your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.357 --> 00:00:04.107
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.107 --> 00:00:08.522
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.522 --> 00:00:11.204
>> Your watching ITProTV.

00:00:11.204 --> 00:00:15.974
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.974 --> 00:00:20.130
I am your host, Mike Rodrick and today,
we are doing our Mac integration basics.

7
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:21.310
And specifically in this episode,

8
00:00:21.310 --> 00:00:23.890
we are gonna be taking a look
at file sharing, right?

9
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:27.700
In a previous episode, we had talked
about directory services, and

10
00:00:27.700 --> 00:00:30.802
getting our MacBook joined
to different directories.

11
00:00:30.802 --> 00:00:33.458
Now that we're part of the network,
maybe we wanna take a look and

12
00:00:33.458 --> 00:00:34.920
see what file shares are out there.

13
00:00:34.920 --> 00:00:36.937
We needed to know how to connect to those,

14
00:00:36.937 --> 00:00:40.560
and here to help us with that is
Mr Don Pezet, welcome back, Don.

15
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:41.566
>> Thanks for having me, Mike,

16
00:00:41.566 --> 00:00:43.997
getting ready to begin our journey in
to the land of share a lot, right?

17
00:00:43.997 --> 00:00:48.010
[LAUGH] So, we're gonna get in here and
see how we can exchange files and

18
00:00:48.010 --> 00:00:50.818
other content in between
different computers.

19
00:00:50.818 --> 00:00:57.020
Now, when you're dealing with Macs,
I've got a MacBook, if Mike has a MacBook,

20
00:00:57.020 --> 00:01:00.150
super easy to share files in between us,
not really a big deal.

21
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:02.988
Where it becomes a challenge
though is on the network.

22
00:01:02.988 --> 00:01:06.743
There are so many different operating
systems that are out there, so

23
00:01:06.743 --> 00:01:11.081
many different ways to store and share
files and folders that it's not as cut and

24
00:01:11.081 --> 00:01:14.836
dry as just, hey, the two systems
automatically find each other and

25
00:01:14.836 --> 00:01:16.030
there you go.

26
00:01:16.030 --> 00:01:18.470
So, when it comes to Mac integration,
right,

27
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:20.700
we're integrating with other
systems that are out there,

28
00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:24.340
we need to be able to talk to
these different types of systems.

29
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:27.540
And fortunately, Apple has taken
care of a lot of that for us.

30
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:32.430
You'll find that your Mac is able to
talk to any number of different services

31
00:01:32.430 --> 00:01:35.970
that are out there, that make it where
you should be able to exchange files with

32
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:38.750
pretty much any other operating
system that you encounter.

33
00:01:38.750 --> 00:01:41.580
Now there's a handful of standard
protocols that are used for

34
00:01:41.580 --> 00:01:45.690
communicating across the network and
some of them happen automatically.

35
00:01:45.690 --> 00:01:48.810
You don't even know it,
you just browse and that's that.

36
00:01:48.810 --> 00:01:51.900
Others have to get a little
bit more involved, right?

37
00:01:51.900 --> 00:01:55.128
If you happen to be working
in an all Apple environment,

38
00:01:55.128 --> 00:02:00.457
then your MacBooks, your iMacs,
your Mac minis, all your MacOS devices,

39
00:02:00.457 --> 00:02:04.210
and even your iOS devices are using
a protocol called Bonjour.

40
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:06.230
And Bonjour lets them find each other.

41
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:07.420
They see each other on the network.

42
00:02:07.420 --> 00:02:08.620
They exchange information and

43
00:02:08.620 --> 00:02:13.390
they use that protocol to make it super
easy to see what's out there, right?

44
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:17.280
And then, they can connect to the file
shares and start to exchange files or

45
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:19.088
connect to a printer or whatever.

46
00:02:19.088 --> 00:02:23.443
And once they start to do that, they're
actually flipping to another protocol

47
00:02:23.443 --> 00:02:26.650
a protocol called AFP,
or Apple File Protocol.

48
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:28.900
And AFP is like the name implies,

49
00:02:28.900 --> 00:02:32.360
developed by Apple for
exchanging files between systems.

50
00:02:32.360 --> 00:02:35.180
And, print jobs really are just
file exchanges, right?

51
00:02:35.180 --> 00:02:39.334
I take a print job, we turn it into
a graphics file, which is just a file and

52
00:02:39.334 --> 00:02:42.818
we transmit it over the network
to a printer or other device and

53
00:02:42.818 --> 00:02:45.170
they take that file and they print it out.

54
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:48.090
So it really is a file transfer even
though it's going to a printer.

55
00:02:48.090 --> 00:02:52.210
That technology is all kind of seamless,
it's in the background,

56
00:02:52.210 --> 00:02:55.220
we don't even notice it,
you don't even really get aware of it.

57
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:57.257
Like, most Mac users have
never even heard of AFP, and

58
00:02:57.257 --> 00:02:59.484
they really shouldn't have
they don't need to know that.

59
00:02:59.484 --> 00:03:01.857
And they may not have heard
of Bonjour either and again,

60
00:03:01.857 --> 00:03:04.860
they shouldn't have it to,
it should be automatic.

61
00:03:04.860 --> 00:03:08.290
But when you're connecting to Windows
systems, or if you're connecting to

62
00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:12.710
Linux systems, it's not like that,
they don't run Bonjour by default.

63
00:03:12.710 --> 00:03:15.590
Although there are versions of Bonjour
that you can put on those to make it where

64
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:17.730
you can discover them,
they don't have it by default.

65
00:03:17.730 --> 00:03:20.900
So, we're not gonna find
Windows machines automatically.

66
00:03:20.900 --> 00:03:25.720
And even if we did, Windows and
Linux use different protocols for

67
00:03:25.720 --> 00:03:27.870
exchanging files, right?

68
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:32.380
It doesn't mean we can't talk to them,
it's just not automatic anymore, right?

69
00:03:32.380 --> 00:03:34.420
Let's take a quick look at what
the automatic piece looks like.

70
00:03:34.420 --> 00:03:36.980
So here I am on a macOS Sierra machine.

71
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:41.831
And, this is a stock install, I haven't
really messed with it too much and

72
00:03:41.831 --> 00:03:46.228
when I fire up my finder,
it's gonna show me, well, all my files.

73
00:03:46.228 --> 00:03:47.589
This is a new machine, so
I don't have any files.

74
00:03:47.589 --> 00:03:48.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's blank.

75
00:03:48.910 --> 00:03:52.150
But, you can look at your Documents,
and your Downloads, your Desktop,

76
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:52.840
all these things.

77
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:55.642
These are files that are right
here on your own machine, right?

78
00:03:55.642 --> 00:03:59.048
And if you choose your Devices, so
here I'm looking at my hard drive,

79
00:03:59.048 --> 00:04:02.630
my Macintosh HD is what it actually says,
there we go, right?

80
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:07.480
But, if I keep scrolling down,
I get to the Shared section, okay,

81
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:08.740
and what is that?

82
00:04:08.740 --> 00:04:12.910
Well now, we're seeing devices
on the network, all right.

83
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:14.770
And your not seeing all
the devices your seeing a subset.

84
00:04:14.770 --> 00:04:17.060
These are usually the devices
that are found first.

85
00:04:17.060 --> 00:04:20.770
So Cameron's Macbook Pro, that's one
of our developers across the building.

86
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:22.240
I'm seeing his MacBook.

87
00:04:22.240 --> 00:04:25.820
Don's MacBook Pro, that's the machine
I'm actually on right now.

88
00:04:25.820 --> 00:04:27.360
Editing Station, Editing Station 2,

89
00:04:27.360 --> 00:04:31.750
that's our editors over there,
right, it's finding these machines.

90
00:04:31.750 --> 00:04:35.660
Now, there's a nice little consistent
pattern across all of these.

91
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:38.370
Every one of these that we're seeing,
actually not every one,

92
00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:41.460
almost every one is a Mac, right?

93
00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:44.108
Cameron's machine, my machine,
the Editing stations, those are all Macs.

94
00:04:44.108 --> 00:04:45.965
lab-server02, that's a Mac.

95
00:04:45.965 --> 00:04:50.230
LAB-SERVER01, it's got a question mark,
it doesn't know what that is, right?

96
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:52.490
Well, I actually messed with
LAB-SERVER01 a good bit.

97
00:04:52.490 --> 00:04:53.840
So it's a Windows machine now, but

98
00:04:53.840 --> 00:04:56.910
it was a Mac before, and so
it's probably cached that.

99
00:04:56.910 --> 00:05:01.140
Mac Mini Studio 2, I'm assuming
is a Mac Mini over in Studio 2.

100
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:02.840
I haven't been over there recently,
so I don't know.

101
00:05:02.840 --> 00:05:07.100
But, it found Macs, and when I go to All,

102
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:10.340
now it's gonna look a little more and
see what it can find out there.

103
00:05:10.340 --> 00:05:13.800
And, there's a few more things that
are showing up, Ronnie's MacBook Pro,

104
00:05:13.800 --> 00:05:18.220
Productron's Encoding Mac,
Tim's iMac 27, all these other systems.

105
00:05:18.220 --> 00:05:19.520
>> Still all Macs there, Don.

106
00:05:19.520 --> 00:05:23.154
>> Still all Macs, and actually though,
if I look at lab-server02,

107
00:05:23.154 --> 00:05:27.420
now I'm questioning because over here,
it had the little computer screen icon.

108
00:05:27.420 --> 00:05:30.993
It's a little insider joke with Apple
that when they detect a Windows machine,

109
00:05:30.993 --> 00:05:34.190
they show a monitor that has the blue
screen of death from Windows on it,

110
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:36.190
which is what Windows
does when it crashes.

111
00:05:36.190 --> 00:05:39.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, that's their little joke.

112
00:05:39.000 --> 00:05:41.570
And it's an old style CRT also, anyhow.

113
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:43.980
>> One little dig.

114
00:05:43.980 --> 00:05:48.378
>> So lab-server02, now I'm curious,
what is lab-server02?

115
00:05:48.378 --> 00:05:50.312
Lab-server02, actually doesn't exist,

116
00:05:50.312 --> 00:05:52.790
I don't know,
lab-server02 now I'm really confused.

117
00:05:52.790 --> 00:05:57.414
So, but it found it on the network,
either way, it's finding this machines and

118
00:05:57.414 --> 00:06:01.850
hopefully I can browse them and
access files and folders, right?

119
00:06:01.850 --> 00:06:04.198
But, when it comes to
connecting to other protocols,

120
00:06:04.198 --> 00:06:07.174
we're not normally gonna be able
to take advantage of this, right?

121
00:06:07.174 --> 00:06:10.195
I'll show you how to get this part
set up a little bit later, but

122
00:06:10.195 --> 00:06:14.244
it doesn't necessarily help us, we're
connecting to another operating system.

123
00:06:14.244 --> 00:06:16.247
When your connecting to
another operating system,

124
00:06:16.247 --> 00:06:19.120
you will typically have to tell
the Mac how to get there, right?

125
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:22.110
In my finder,
I don't have a ton of options here for

126
00:06:22.110 --> 00:06:23.790
connecting to other systems.

127
00:06:23.790 --> 00:06:28.667
But, up top in my menus up here, you
see the Go menu and we could choose Go,

128
00:06:28.667 --> 00:06:32.162
and right down here,
you have, Connect to server.

129
00:06:32.162 --> 00:06:33.320
And this is what we can use for

130
00:06:33.320 --> 00:06:36.500
connecting to systems that
weren't automatically discovered.

131
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:40.340
When you chose Connect to Server, you get
this little dialogue box that pops up

132
00:06:40.340 --> 00:06:42.860
that'll let you type in a Server Address,
right?

133
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:47.000
Now, you can choose Browse, and browse
will let you browse the network to try to

134
00:06:47.000 --> 00:06:50.250
find things, but, we just saw how
effective that was on my system.

135
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:50.760
I know for

136
00:06:50.760 --> 00:06:54.160
a fact there's at least one Windows server
out there that didn't get detected.

137
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:56.570
So, there's systems that it's not finding.

138
00:06:56.570 --> 00:07:02.910
So, Browse works sometimes, but
it's not perfect, Server Address, though.

139
00:07:02.910 --> 00:07:06.610
I can manually type in the address of
a server that I wanna connect to, and

140
00:07:06.610 --> 00:07:07.830
I can get there.

141
00:07:07.830 --> 00:07:08.867
Now when I, go ahead.

142
00:07:08.867 --> 00:07:10.436
>> And Don, when this says server,

143
00:07:10.436 --> 00:07:14.023
what if my buddy has a MacBook that he
shared something with, is this only for

144
00:07:14.023 --> 00:07:16.485
connecting to servers or
other machines as well?

145
00:07:16.485 --> 00:07:17.935
>> It could really be anything, right?

146
00:07:17.935 --> 00:07:21.005
Because the way a server shares files is
not really any different than the way

147
00:07:21.005 --> 00:07:21.885
a workstation shares files.

148
00:07:21.885 --> 00:07:24.355
The only thing that's really different
is how we authenticate, right?

149
00:07:24.355 --> 00:07:27.315
Workstations normally have
their own unique user database.

150
00:07:27.315 --> 00:07:29.055
Servers are typically
a part of a directory but

151
00:07:29.055 --> 00:07:31.520
they might have their own unique
database too, it just depends.

152
00:07:31.520 --> 00:07:34.035
At this point,
when we connect to a network share,

153
00:07:34.035 --> 00:07:37.030
we don't really know if it's a server or
a workstation.

154
00:07:37.030 --> 00:07:39.060
It could be either one, all right?

155
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:41.264
The other thing is,
there's more than one protocol out there.

156
00:07:41.264 --> 00:07:43.602
So when we specify a server here,

157
00:07:43.602 --> 00:07:48.876
what we actually need to specify is at
a minimum two pieces of information.

158
00:07:48.876 --> 00:07:54.470
A protocol, and then the user will be
like, ://, and then a server name, right?

159
00:07:54.470 --> 00:07:58.627
Those are the two pieces of information
it needs to connect to a server.

160
00:07:58.627 --> 00:08:02.100
You might also be able to pass a user
name and a password in this URL.

161
00:08:02.100 --> 00:08:06.020
And the way that looks
is you'll see where it's

162
00:08:06.020 --> 00:08:11.220
a username:password@ and
the servername like that.

163
00:08:11.220 --> 00:08:14.560
Right starting to get a little
more complex on that line.

164
00:08:14.560 --> 00:08:18.120
We don't normally do that, because if
it requires a username and a password

165
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:21.540
then when you browse through it through
a prompt, the username and the password.

166
00:08:21.540 --> 00:08:23.120
The other thing is if you
ever put the username and

167
00:08:23.120 --> 00:08:26.160
password right here in line with the URL,
it sent unencrypted over the network.

168
00:08:26.160 --> 00:08:27.930
And that's not a great thing either.

169
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:30.080
We'd rather wait and
let it prompt us and then, hopefully,

170
00:08:30.080 --> 00:08:32.010
we'll have a secured session from there.

171
00:08:32.010 --> 00:08:34.510
But, these are the two pieces of
information I need to provide.

172
00:08:34.510 --> 00:08:35.880
A protocol and a server name.

173
00:08:35.880 --> 00:08:37.440
So let's start with protocol.

174
00:08:37.440 --> 00:08:39.610
The protocol can be any number of things.

175
00:08:39.610 --> 00:08:43.890
I mentioned with Apple we normally
use AFP, Apple file protocol.

176
00:08:43.890 --> 00:08:45.920
So if you're connecting to another
Apple device, you can use it.

177
00:08:45.920 --> 00:08:49.040
But if you're connecting with another
Apple device you probably would have just

178
00:08:49.040 --> 00:08:50.730
used browse because
you'll find it that way.

179
00:08:50.730 --> 00:08:52.350
Unless it's on a different network, right?

180
00:08:52.350 --> 00:08:54.740
Maybe you're reaching through
a router to a different subnet and

181
00:08:54.740 --> 00:08:57.840
Bonjour doesn't work in
between subnets like that.

182
00:08:57.840 --> 00:09:01.440
So we have to manually specify
the DNS name or the IP address.

183
00:09:01.440 --> 00:09:06.610
So the system that we're connecting to and
then the protocol.

184
00:09:08.250 --> 00:09:10.080
Other protocols that are support though.

185
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:13.210
If I'm connecting to Linux or Unix server,

186
00:09:13.210 --> 00:09:19.200
remember that Maco S is running Unix under
hood, so BST environment under the hood.

187
00:09:19.200 --> 00:09:22.810
So it can connect those using NFS,
the Network File System.

188
00:09:22.810 --> 00:09:26.780
NFS has been around a long time,
since the 1980s.

189
00:09:26.780 --> 00:09:30.210
It's supported by every Linux and
Unix distribution that's out there and

190
00:09:30.210 --> 00:09:31.300
every BSD.

191
00:09:31.300 --> 00:09:36.060
So if you're connecting to any Linux
distro, Free BSD, Open BSD, those guys,

192
00:09:36.060 --> 00:09:39.060
Solaris, any of those
other Unix like systems,

193
00:09:39.060 --> 00:09:40.400
you can use NFS to connect to them.

194
00:09:40.400 --> 00:09:42.550
And there's even NFS servers for
Windows too.

195
00:09:42.550 --> 00:09:45.300
So NFS is the one that you
can kind of get working on

196
00:09:45.300 --> 00:09:46.630
every operating system if you need to.

197
00:09:48.040 --> 00:09:51.530
There's FTP,
FTP's been around a long time also.

198
00:09:51.530 --> 00:09:53.750
File Transfer Protocol.

199
00:09:53.750 --> 00:09:56.760
FTP is nice in that everybody supports it,
but

200
00:09:56.760 --> 00:09:59.650
it's not nice in that it's
completely unencrypted,

201
00:09:59.650 --> 00:10:02.520
even the user name and password are
transmitted across the network insecurely.

202
00:10:02.520 --> 00:10:04.450
So it's not perfect by any means.

203
00:10:04.450 --> 00:10:09.680
But it is something that is still
supported, because if you're

204
00:10:09.680 --> 00:10:14.980
just doing non sensitive transfers, FTP
is quick and easy to get up and running.

205
00:10:14.980 --> 00:10:19.160
Then we've got things like HTTP,
right, if you were browsing the web,

206
00:10:19.160 --> 00:10:22.810
now, I'm not browsing the web, if I was,
I'd usually fire up Safari, or Chrome, or

207
00:10:22.810 --> 00:10:24.210
something like that, and
browse to it that way, so

208
00:10:24.210 --> 00:10:28.950
we wouldn't normally do it here but
there is a service called WebDAV.

209
00:10:28.950 --> 00:10:33.220
WebDAV is web distributed authoring and
versioning.

210
00:10:33.220 --> 00:10:36.360
And what it allows you to do is to
connect to a file server using HTTP.

211
00:10:36.360 --> 00:10:39.320
And this was popular in
the early days of the Internet

212
00:10:39.320 --> 00:10:42.300
where you had web developers that
wanted to connect to a web server and

213
00:10:42.300 --> 00:10:45.720
be able to edit the HTML files and

00:23:54.389 --> 00:23:56.430
you only have so much memory so
eventually it is.

464
00:23:56.430 --> 00:24:00.278
But each time a library is loaded,
it's loaded in a different place.

465
00:24:00.278 --> 00:24:02.700
And that makes it very difficult for
an attacker to target.

466
00:24:02.700 --> 00:24:05.380
And it's not just libraries,
even the kernel is done that way,

467
00:24:05.380 --> 00:24:08.520
the kernel itself, which is incredibly
difficult to tamper with anyway.

468
00:24:08.520 --> 00:24:11.620
But better safe then sorry,
Apple takes that extra step and

469
00:24:11.620 --> 00:24:12.780
makes sure that that's being randomized.

470
00:24:12.780 --> 00:24:15.560
So library randomization,
it's not something we have to turn on.

471
00:24:15.560 --> 00:24:17.050
It's not even something
I can really show you.

472
00:24:17.050 --> 00:24:19.490
It's just something that
happens in the background,

473
00:24:19.490 --> 00:24:21.490
it is an extra step
protecting us from attackers.

474
00:24:22.990 --> 00:24:24.385
And then the last one I wanna mention,

475
00:24:24.385 --> 00:24:26.358
is actually a function of your processor,
your CPU.

476
00:24:26.358 --> 00:24:31.736
There's a function in Intel processors,
called execute disable, right.

477
00:24:31.736 --> 00:24:33.886
And sometimes it's called
the no execute bit, but

478
00:24:33.886 --> 00:24:36.370
execute disables what
it's actually called.

479
00:24:36.370 --> 00:24:39.370
And, what it does is it
says when a program runs,

480
00:24:44.860 --> 00:24:45.686
a program is expected to access
a certain area of memory.

481
00:24:45.686 --> 00:24:46.800
And there's other areas of memory that
a program is not expected to access.

482
00:24:46.800 --> 00:24:48.750
Like where our kernel's running from.

483
00:24:48.750 --> 00:24:51.210
And so the processor can recognize that.

484
00:24:51.210 --> 00:24:56.530
And when an application tries to
execute code in the wrong memory space,

485
00:24:56.530 --> 00:25:00.550
it can stop that, it can disable
the executor, do a no execute.

486
00:25:00.550 --> 00:25:04.510
And prevent an application from reaching
into another application's memory space.

487
00:25:04.510 --> 00:25:07.770
Now, that should never happen anyway,
right?

488
00:25:07.770 --> 00:25:11.200
But attackers love to do
buffer overflow attacks.

489
00:25:11.200 --> 00:25:15.960
And buffer overflow are where they throw
so much junk into memory that it fills up

490
00:25:15.960 --> 00:25:19.660
the memory assigned to an application, and
it overflows into the next application.

491
00:25:19.660 --> 00:25:22.760
And that's when they might be able
to overflow into the kernel or

492
00:25:22.760 --> 00:25:25.450
some of the privileged space and
gain higher privileges.

493
00:25:25.450 --> 00:25:30.210
While your CPU can stop that, assuming
that your Operating System is aware.

494
00:25:30.210 --> 00:25:35.140
And Mac OS is fully aware, and Apple
only uses Intel processors, so it's got

495
00:25:35.140 --> 00:25:38.920
that functionality baked in and that's
another one we can take advantage of.

496
00:25:38.920 --> 00:25:42.992
We don't turn it on or turn it off, right,
you usually see it on a regular computer,

497
00:25:42.992 --> 00:25:45.810
like a Windows machine,
you'd see it as a BIOS option.

498
00:25:45.810 --> 00:25:48.490
But on a Mac you don't
have access to the BIOS.

499
00:25:48.490 --> 00:25:51.160
It's enabled, it's turned on,
there's no way to disable it.

500
00:25:51.160 --> 00:25:53.460
And it's protecting you
on a regular basis.

501
00:25:53.460 --> 00:25:57.610
So, system integrity protection,
library randomization,

502
00:25:57.610 --> 00:25:59.460
the execute disable functionality.

503
00:25:59.460 --> 00:26:02.660
These are all things that are working
behind the scenes to protect us.

504
00:26:02.660 --> 00:26:06.060
And, I didn't show you guys a single
configuration command this whole episode.

505
00:26:06.060 --> 00:26:07.860
We dont' have to turn them on,
they're just running, they're there,

506
00:26:07.860 --> 00:26:10.200
and they protect us and make it safer.

507
00:26:10.200 --> 00:26:13.080
>> All right Don, fantastic look
at some of the security features

508
00:26:13.080 --> 00:26:17.360
built into Mac OS that, as you said,
are just there helping keep us safe.

509
00:26:17.360 --> 00:26:21.690
So we appreciate that great explanation
of how it uses the sandboxing and

510
00:26:21.690 --> 00:26:24.530
the system integrity
protection to keep us safe.

511
00:26:24.530 --> 00:26:25.320
So we thank you for that.

512
00:26:25.320 --> 00:26:27.640
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

513
00:26:27.640 --> 00:26:30.570
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

514
00:26:30.570 --> 00:26:31.280
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

515
00:26:31.280 --> 00:26:33.513
>> And we'll see you next time.

516
00:26:33.513 --> 00:26:39.467
[MUSIC]

517
00:26:39.467 --> 00:26:42.571
Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike continue their look at security features in MacOS. They look at how the Password Assistant can be used to help generate strong passwords. They also demonstrate multi-factor authentication.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.848
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.848 --> 00:00:05.985
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.985 --> 00:00:08.220
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.220 --> 00:00:10.640
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.540 --> 00:00:15.430
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.430 --> 00:00:19.190
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing our Mac integration basics.

7
00:00:19.190 --> 00:00:24.320
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at our security features.

8
00:00:24.320 --> 00:00:26.218
And here to help us with
that is Mr Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.218 --> 00:00:27.595
Welcome back, Don.

10
00:00:27.595 --> 00:00:28.505
>> Welcome back, Mike.

11
00:00:28.505 --> 00:00:31.355
I'm ready to jump right back
into the hole, security world.

12
00:00:31.355 --> 00:00:33.825
We got a lot of security topics to cover.

13
00:00:33.825 --> 00:00:37.231
So, it's just a ton of neat little
add ons, little pieces that

14
00:00:37.231 --> 00:00:41.170
are part of Mac OS that all together
create a really secure environment.

15
00:00:41.170 --> 00:00:42.994
We got to see a couple of
those in part one, but

16
00:00:42.994 --> 00:00:44.638
now we're gonna pick up with a few more.

17
00:00:44.638 --> 00:00:47.570
And we're gonna start with
something that is kind of important

18
00:00:47.570 --> 00:00:48.846
which is password security.

19
00:00:48.846 --> 00:00:49.931
>> Right, that's very important.

20
00:00:49.931 --> 00:00:54.568
>> I mention it here because, Macs, Apples
in general, one of their marketing angles

21
00:00:54.568 --> 00:00:57.590
is the fact that their devices
are easy to use you know?

22
00:00:57.590 --> 00:01:01.178
If you get an iPod, or
an iPhone, an iPad, an iMac,

23
00:01:01.178 --> 00:01:06.410
a MacBook, they're all designed
to be super easy and convenient.

24
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:09.068
Well, what is easy and
convenient about typing in a password?

25
00:01:09.068 --> 00:01:10.464
>> Nothing.
>> Nothing.

26
00:01:10.464 --> 00:01:12.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, for a lot of people,

27
00:01:12.000 --> 00:01:15.150
when they get a new MacBook Air or
MacBook Pro or

28
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:18.240
whatever and
they run through that initial setup, and

29
00:01:18.240 --> 00:01:22.470
they see the password is optional,
they might not set a password.

30
00:01:22.470 --> 00:01:25.093
Or they set a password but
then they turn on automatic log on, so

31
00:01:25.093 --> 00:01:28.181
that when they turn on their computer,
it just immediately logs them in.

32
00:01:28.181 --> 00:01:31.590
All right, well,
that can be a problem, right?

33
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:34.930
If you lose your laptop, if I leave
it on a cab, and somebody gets it and

34
00:01:34.930 --> 00:01:37.110
opens it up at auto logs in,

35
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:42.510
that's gonna give somebody access to your
system and potentially access your files.

36
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:46.250
So, we generally, wants to make sure
that we have a password set and

37
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:49.350
then it's a strong password,
not an easy one to guess.

38
00:01:49.350 --> 00:01:51.500
That is not password one, two, three.

39
00:01:51.500 --> 00:01:56.600
Or what Mike use is one, two, three, four
or just your, [LAUGH] pause the video or

40
00:01:56.600 --> 00:02:01.112
our birthday that you people know
your birthday, if you celebrate it.

41
00:02:01.112 --> 00:02:03.628
So, those are things
that people can guess.

42
00:02:03.628 --> 00:02:05.880
And we wanna make sure that we have
strong passwords that are hard for

43
00:02:05.880 --> 00:02:07.020
people to guess.

44
00:02:07.020 --> 00:02:11.520
And so to help with that, Apple has
a feature called the Password Assistant.

45
00:02:11.520 --> 00:02:15.280
And the Password Assistant helps you
to generate a password that is secure.

46
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:17.240
And, it usually, I'm gonna say,
usually shows up,

47
00:02:17.240 --> 00:02:18.569
it shows up in the important places.

48
00:02:18.569 --> 00:02:21.890
It shows up when you're assigning
a password to a user account.

49
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:26.100
But it also shows up in a number of
other password fields throughout macOS.

50
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:29.230
So, anytime you go to get to a field
where you're generating a password,

51
00:02:29.230 --> 00:02:31.740
you may see a special little key icon,

52
00:02:31.740 --> 00:02:34.810
it's letting you know the password
assistant is ready to help you.

53
00:02:34.810 --> 00:02:36.520
Let me show you one user account.

54
00:02:36.520 --> 00:02:38.880
So I'm gonna go into my
System Preferences, and

55
00:02:38.880 --> 00:02:41.650
I'm gonna dig into my Users and
Groups, right?

56
00:02:41.650 --> 00:02:43.760
So when I go into Users and
Groups, I'll see all the users and

57
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:45.060
groups here on my system.

58
00:02:45.060 --> 00:02:47.591
And, if I wanna make any changes,
here I need to unlock it.

59
00:02:47.591 --> 00:02:52.420
And actually, that's a good, well,
I gotta remember my password here.

60
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:56.581
But, a good thing to point out is, even if
your user account is set to auto log in,

61
00:02:56.581 --> 00:03:00.318
when you perform an administrative task,
you do still have to unlock and

62
00:03:00.318 --> 00:03:01.710
provide a password.

63
00:03:01.710 --> 00:03:05.360
So that automated log in, isn't
necessarily gonna compromise the safety of

64
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:09.280
your system, but it will compromise
the safety of your data, right.

65
00:03:09.280 --> 00:03:12.560
Somebody could turn on your laptop,
it automatically logs you in, and

66
00:03:12.560 --> 00:03:14.100
now they can get to your
documents folder and

67
00:03:14.100 --> 00:03:17.610
they can save it all to a USB key and
walk away with your data, right?

68
00:03:17.610 --> 00:03:18.810
But, they wouldn't be able to come in and

69
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:21.570
reset the password of an account,
unless they had your password.

70
00:03:21.570 --> 00:03:24.810
So there's that,
unless you left your password empty,

71
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:27.950
if you didn't have a password, in which
case then you'd have a bigger problem.

72
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.200
So if I wanna take a user though,

73
00:03:29.200 --> 00:03:33.360
I'll take somebody like old
Christopher Walkin here, and this user,

74
00:03:33.360 --> 00:03:37.580
I can reset their password, and
I can assign a password to them.

75
00:03:37.580 --> 00:03:40.350
And usually, we just type in whatever
that password is gonna be and

76
00:03:40.350 --> 00:03:42.200
maybe we put in a hint or maybe we don't.

77
00:03:42.200 --> 00:03:44.200
I generally don't put
a hint on my accounts, but

78
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:46.320
you might wanna have to put
one out to help you remember.

79
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:50.000
Remember that a password hint
not only helps you remember, but

80
00:03:50.000 --> 00:03:51.870
helps an attacker guess, right?

81
00:03:51.870 --> 00:03:53.490
So it needs to be a cryptic hint,

82
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:56.340
which in my opinion at that point
you might as well not have.

83
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:57.044
So, that's up to you.

84
00:03:57.044 --> 00:03:57.962
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

85
00:03:57.962 --> 00:03:59.795
this key icon that's what
I really wanna talk about.

86
00:03:59.795 --> 00:04:03.580
That key icon is the Password Assistant.

87
00:04:03.580 --> 00:04:08.033
And when you hit it, it launches this
little window down here, which is well,

88
00:04:08.033 --> 00:04:11.550
the Password Assistant and
it helps you generate a password.

89
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:15.620
And there's several different
ways it can generate a password,

90
00:04:15.620 --> 00:04:18.590
the default is called Memorable.

91
00:04:18.590 --> 00:04:21.390
Memorable is where it takes
a couple of words and

92
00:04:21.390 --> 00:04:24.340
it strings together a few
special characters in it to

93
00:04:24.340 --> 00:04:29.240
create something that is complex but
easy to remember, right?

94
00:04:29.240 --> 00:04:33.926
So here roses3, looks like a quote
mark and then jives, so roses3"jives,

95
00:04:33.926 --> 00:04:36.626
all right', that's not hard to remember.

96
00:04:36.626 --> 00:04:37.764
>> Not too bad.

97
00:04:37.764 --> 00:04:39.890
Yeah, yeah the four things it'll
be like remembering four letters,

98
00:04:39.890 --> 00:04:40.656
it's pretty easy to do.

99
00:04:40.656 --> 00:04:44.725
Now these are dictionary words, so
in theory a dictionary attack might get it

100
00:04:44.725 --> 00:04:47.980
but the special characters
in the middle help.

101
00:04:47.980 --> 00:04:52.370
This password though isn't necessarily
as strong as we'd like to see, right?

102
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:54.330
The official Apple recommendation,

103
00:04:54.330 --> 00:04:58.330
the one you'll see on the exam
is at least eight characters.

104
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:01.145
Well, we've got more than eight
characters here so, we're good.

105
00:05:01.145 --> 00:05:04.855
At least one upper case and
one lower case character.

106
00:05:04.855 --> 00:05:06.655
Well, that's where this one breaks down,
right,

107
00:05:06.655 --> 00:05:10.015
there's no uppercase characters in here,
it's all lower case.

108
00:05:10.015 --> 00:05:13.867
So we might need to modify that if we
needed to meet our recommendations.

109
00:05:13.867 --> 00:05:17.279
At least one number, we've got 3,
and at least one special character,

110
00:05:17.279 --> 00:05:19.010
we've got a quote mark, all right?

111
00:05:19.010 --> 00:05:23.420
So, it's generating a password here and
suggesting it to me.

112
00:05:23.420 --> 00:05:27.860
And, if I wanna modify that, it's gonna
rank the quality here to determine

113
00:05:27.860 --> 00:05:30.620
whether it's a better or
a weaker password.

114
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:34.820
Now, this little Quality marker here,
notice how it's just saying Entropy 0.0.

115
00:05:34.820 --> 00:05:37.740
It's not actually measuring anything
right now, cuz it's auto generated.

116
00:05:37.740 --> 00:05:41.880
But if I start to modify the password,
now it generates, right?

117
00:05:41.880 --> 00:05:45.660
And so I can see that, I've got
a certain level of entropy now, 79.4.

118
00:05:45.660 --> 00:05:51.820
And if I go back and I take something out,
like if I just did rosesjives.

119
00:05:51.820 --> 00:05:54.650
See how my score dropped way low and

120
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:57.291
it did that because now I
just got two dictionary word.

121
00:05:57.291 --> 00:06:01.870
That can be brute forced, somebody can
guess that with a multiple attempt,

122
00:06:01.870 --> 00:06:03.360
it's not that hard.

123
00:06:03.360 --> 00:06:07.250
But the moment we added that number in,
that number,

124
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:09.780
that quality number jumped quite a bit,
right?

125
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:12.402
I went from 13 to 56.9.

126
00:06:12.402 --> 00:06:17.660
And then when we added the " mark in,
now we've gone even higher to 73.3.

127
00:06:17.660 --> 00:06:22.360
Well, the more complexity you introduce,
the stronger this is getting.

128
00:06:22.360 --> 00:06:24.590
See how that numbers
kinda continues to go up?

129
00:06:24.590 --> 00:06:28.557
There is a diminishing return at one
point where it won't get stronger

130
00:06:28.557 --> 00:06:29.640
anymore, right?

131
00:06:29.640 --> 00:06:31.890
Where it's just like, hey,
you're passwords strong enough.

132
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:34.970
But, the point is here, that you
wanna create a strong password that

133
00:06:34.970 --> 00:06:37.350
meets the needs of you and
your organization.

134
00:06:37.350 --> 00:06:38.610
You want it to be secure.

135
00:06:38.610 --> 00:06:41.500
But not so
secure that you can't remember it.

136
00:06:41.500 --> 00:06:42.970
Now, Memorable is one way,

137
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:45.675
see how it changed to Manual
now cuz I messed with it.

138
00:06:45.675 --> 00:06:46.380
>> Yeah.

139
00:06:46.380 --> 00:06:49.536
>> If you drop that box down,
you'll see there's other ones too, right,

140
00:06:49.536 --> 00:06:51.430
like Letters & Numbers.

141
00:06:51.430 --> 00:06:55.000
Letters and numbers are nice cuz,
well, they're letters and numbers,

142
00:06:55.000 --> 00:06:57.590
right, no special characters.

143
00:06:57.590 --> 00:07:00.640
Well, you can still get a strong
password without special characters.

144
00:07:00.640 --> 00:07:02.940
You just have to have a lot of them,
right?

145
00:07:02.940 --> 00:07:06.160
And try and have true randomness,
which is hard for humans to do.

146
00:07:06.160 --> 00:07:09.520
So, here it's a pretty strong password,
even though it has no special characters.

147
00:07:09.520 --> 00:07:12.590
If I stuck even one special character
on there, though, it would help.

148
00:07:12.590 --> 00:07:15.810
But without that, it's still
a certain degree of strength, right?

149
00:07:15.810 --> 00:07:19.040
There's capital and or
uppercase and lowercase letters.

150
00:07:19.040 --> 00:07:22.370
There's numbers, so this is really just
missing the special characters item.

151
00:07:23.420 --> 00:07:25.667
>> But
not really easy to remember on that one.

152
00:07:25.667 --> 00:07:26.805
[LAUGH]
>> No, this is one that would end up on

153
00:07:26.805 --> 00:07:27.993
a Post-it notes stuck to your monitor.

154
00:07:27.993 --> 00:07:30.068
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, all right,

155
00:07:30.068 --> 00:07:32.800
if we drop that down,
then you'll see there's Numbers Only.

156
00:07:32.800 --> 00:07:36.865
Notice with Numbers Only, it really
didn't get a good strength, right,

157
00:07:36.865 --> 00:07:39.136
because numbers are easy to brute force.

158
00:07:39.136 --> 00:07:43.276
They can start with 1, and then 2,
and then 3, and then 4 and

159
00:07:43.276 --> 00:07:47.960
after enough attempts eventually,
they come across whatever this is,

160
00:07:47.960 --> 00:07:50.670
77 trillion 808 billion whatever.

161
00:07:50.670 --> 00:07:53.020
So, it would take them a while,
but they'd get there eventually.

162
00:07:54.632 --> 00:07:59.473
All right, we have Random, which is
trying to achieve true randomness.

163
00:07:59.473 --> 00:08:00.867
All letters, all numbers,

164
00:08:00.867 --> 00:08:03.897
all special characters are involved
here in being rendered.

165
00:08:03.897 --> 00:08:07.260
Now When we look at this,
there was one that was numbers only,

166
00:08:07.260 --> 00:08:11.270
versus this one that has letters and,
I'm sorry, it was numbers only but

167
00:08:11.270 --> 00:08:14.650
we also saw letters and
numbers without special characters.

168
00:08:14.650 --> 00:08:16.707
And here we have a lot

00:24:26.900 --> 00:24:29.590

00:24:29.590 --> 00:24:32.980
Because that's you providing the private

00:24:32.980 --> 00:24:35.980

00:24:35.980 --> 00:24:38.361
